rest.sentence: The hole transport layer /anode interface plays an important role in high-performance regular Ag-based perovskite solar cells

Usually, the charge barrier caused by the energy level mismatch at the HTL/Ag interface will lead to the abnormal s-type J-V curve, which seriously hindering the commercial application of Ag-based PSCs
Here, we introduce a solution processed molybdenum oxide  into the HTL/Ag interface to form a double-hole HTL
The work function  of HxMoO3 films can be adjusted by controlling the reaction time
The introduction of HxMoO3 can effectively change the energy-level bending orientation, promote the charge transport and suppresses carrier recombination, thus eliminate the s-type J-V curve
Finally, the Ag-based PSCs achieve a power conversion efficiency  of 23.16%
Meanwhile, the PCE of the four-terminal  perovskite/silicon tandem cell reaches 26.76%
Furthermore, the HxMoO3 can also be used as a protective layer to prevent the erosion of moisture on the PSCs and the penetration of the silver electrode, improving the stability of the devices
This provides an important reference for the development of perovskites and their tandem solar cells.
Download : Download high-res image Download : Download full-size image
Perovskite solar cells  have received extensive attention because of their simple fabrication process and excellent optoelectronic properties
Since 2009, the efficiency of single- and multi-junction perovskite devices achieved rapid development
,  The cost and stability issues have been an important issue in the commercialization process of regular PSCs
,  Among the state-of-the-art n-i-p structured PSCs, Spiro-OMeTAD/Au is the most commonly used combination due to the matched energy band alignment
,  However, due to the high price of gold, the manufacturing cost of PSCs is greatly increased, which hinders the commercial operation of PSCs
Although researchers have used a variety of materials to replace Au to reduce manufacturing costs, these devices are still less efficient than Au-based perovskite solar cells

Recently, Ag has been considered as one of the most potential alternative materials to replace Au due to its lower price and higher conductivity, while the efficiency of Ag-based perovskite solar cells has approached that of Au-based perovskite solar cells
However, the charge barrier between silver and HTL often leads to an abnormal s-type J-V curve of the device, and the s-type J-V curve changes to a normal one over time
The researchers found that the recovery time required for the J-V curve is indeterminate , which affects the stability and repeatability of the devices

In addition, the Ag electrode can penetrate into the Spiro-OMeTAD and react with iodine ions in the perovskite layer to form silver iodide, which also affects the carrier transport and devices stability
,  To solve the above problems, several methods have been successfully applied to perovskite solar cells
The solution processed AgI buffer layers have been added between HTL/Ag to regulate the interfacial energy levels, which effectively eliminates the s-shaped J-V curves of fresh PSCs
Although the solution processed AgI buffer layer provides more operational possibilities, the efficiency of Ag-based PSCs is still lower than that of Au-based PSCs
In addition, the evaporated-MoO3 buffer layer is also used at the HTL/Ag interface to adjust the interfacial contact barrier and improve the devices stability
,  The PCE of Ag-PSCs based on the evaporated-MoO3 is comparable to that of Au-based PSCs
However, evaporated MoO3 requires precise thickness regulation, or it will increase charge transfer resistance leading to low PCE
In general, effective regulation of Spiro-OMeTAD/Ag interfacial energy levels and inhibition of adverse reactions of Ag electrodes are crucial to improve the efficiency and stability of Ag-based PSCs

Meanwhile, a protective layer needs to be deposited between Spiro-OMeTAD and ITO during the fabrication of perovskite/silicon tandem solar cells  to prevent damage to Spiro-OMeTAD during the ITO sputtering process
,  Therefore, there is an urgent need to find a simple method to fabricate the efficient and stable Ag-based PSCs.
Here, we chemically synthesized a molybdenum oxide  ethanol solution, and introduced HxMoO3 into the interface between Spiro-OMeTAD and Ag by spin coating to form a double-hole HTL
The properties of HxMoO3 films can be adjusted by controlling the reaction time to affect the Mo5+/Mo6+ ratio

Compared with the conventional MoO3, which requires expensive manufacturing equipment and high temperature, the solutioned-HxMoO3 layer is prepared by low temperature method, which has the advantages of adjustable energy level and simple process, and does not require the support of expensive equipment
Meanwhile, alcohol solvent will not cause damage to Spiro-OMeTAD
It has remarkable effect on improving device performance and stability
The introduction of HxMoO3 can change the energy level bending orientation, thereby eliminating the s-type J-V curve
Various characterization methods show that the introduction of HxMoO3 layer can improve the hole transport properties, reduce charge recombination and enhance the photovoltaic performance of PSCs
Finally, the Ag-based perovskite device based on the HxMoO3 double-hole HTL achieved a PCE of 23.16%
Meanwhile, the PCE of the four-terminal perovskite/silicon tandem cell based on HxMoO3 reached 26.76%

In addition, as a protective layer, HxMoO3 can block the erosion of moisture and prevent the Ag electrode from penetrating into Spiro-OMeTAD and reacting with iodide ions in the perovskite layer and, which makes a great contribution to improving the stability of the device.
When Ag electrode was deposited on Spiro-OMeTAD, the PSC initially showed s-type J-V curve
With the increase of time, the s-type J-V curve gradually recovers to show a normal J-V curve, and the device performance reaches the best state, as shown in Fig

Jung and coworkers found that the aging-induced recovery phenomenon of Ag-electrode based devices was due to a change in the high hole injection barrier between the HTL and the metal electrode due to the energy level mismatch1a

In summary, we formed a double-HTL by introducing solution-prepared HxMoO3 film between the interface of Spiro-OMeTAD/Ag, which can effectively optimize the band bending at Spiro-OMeTAD/Ag interface and eliminate the abnormal s-type J-V curve
Meanwhile, the properties of HxMoO3 films can be adjusted by controlling the Mo5+/Mo6+ ratio, which is affected by the reaction time
Moreover, the introduction of HxMoO3 promoted the charge transport between Spiro-OMeTAD and Ag electrodes, suppressed the

In order to obtain high power conversion efficiency and high stability perovskite solar cells, many innovative optimization schemes have been proposed
Thereinto, the interface modification become an effective way to improve the performance of device
Here, A dual-interface passivation by 2, 3, 4, 5, 6-pentafluorophenylammonium bromide-based  is used to optimize the performance of device with the structure of ITO/SnO2/perovskite/PTAA/Ag
We design the 5PFP-Br layer at SnO2/perovskite and perovskite/PTAA interface respectively
The results show that the interface contact between perovskite and charge transport layer is improved obviously
At the same time, the density of carrier transport defect states in the device is reduced, thus reducing the non-radiative recombination of carriers

Meanwhile, the 5PFP-Br layer at perovskite/PTAA interface can effectively passivate Pb defects and reduce the number of grain boundaries in perovskite film, and increase the carrier transfer and collection efficiency
Finally, 5PFP-Br double-interface passivation can further optimize and improve the performance of device
The device based 5PFP-Br double-interface passivation presents an increased efficiency from 18.09% to 21.15%, where FF is raised from 73.30% to 80.04%
At the same time, unpackaged device can still be maintained to more than 90% efficiency after about 1200 h at 25 °C and 25%RH.

To investigate the isomeric effect of meta and para indolocarbazole-based hole transport materials on the performance of perovskite solar cells , we herein design and synthesize two isomers  as hole transporting layers  for inverted PSCs
Compared with m-PFICZ, the highest occupied molecular orbital energy level of p-PFICZ is deeper, which reduces the energy loss of hole extraction at the HTL/perovskite interface
Furthermore, p-PFICZ forms closer molecular stacking and more compact film than m-PFICZ, resulting in higher hole mobility for the former
Owing to the isomeric effect, the inverted PSC based on p-PFICZ as the HTL obtains a power conversion efficiency  of 21.39 %, which is 8 % enhancement relative to the device based on m-PFICZ
In addition, the devices based on p-PFICZ have better air and thermal stabilities than the m-PFICZ based devices due to the lower trap density and slower charge recombination rate for the former

The p-PFICZ-based PSC maintains 92 % of the initial PCE against 83 % for the m-PFICZ-based device after being stored in an ambient condition for 1000 h, and the former retains 82 % of the initial PCE against 70 % for the latter after continuous heating at 85 °C for 600 h
The findings of this work provide a new strategy for the performance optimization of PSCs.
For fully-air-processed perovskite solar cells , high-quality perovskite films and improved intrinsic stability are critical for high photovoltaic performance
However, strain, as a critical factor of perovskite instability, not only harms the efficiency of PSCs but also accelerates the degradation of the PSCs devices

In this report, we introduce a novel negative thermal expansion  material into perovskite film for the first time, growing a high-quality perovskite films with high crystallinity, large grain size and low defect density

More importantly, effective residual strain relaxation of perovskite films is achieved, the thermal expansion compensation properties of NTE materials reduces the overall thermal expansion coefficient for perovskite films
As a result, the fully-air processed PSC achieves a champion power conversion efficiency  of 22.40 %
Simultaneously, the unencapsulated device retains 93.78 % of its original PCE after storage in ambient air after 90 days
Furthermore, these devices also show excellent thermal stability and remarkable light stability
The present study not only provides insights into the multi role of NTE materials, but also provides a new path for the application of NTE materials in the photovoltaic field.
Perovskite solar cells  with dopant‐free hole transporting layers  deserved extensive research by merits of their outstanding hydrophobicity and stability
However, the low carrier mobility and poor interfacial hole extraction lead to the inferior power conversion efficiency  than that of conventional Li+ doped Spiro-OMeTAD
Here, a design of triphenylamine groups grafted triphenylene derivative  as dopant-free HTLs has been presented
The larger π-conjugation in T-6TPA give rise to high hole mobility of 2.06 × 10−3 cm2V−1s−1
Moreover, the interfacial hole extraction of T-6TPA was significantly promoted when the molecules were infiltrated into perovskite before HTL deposition
The infiltration method of anti-solvent dripping  strategy increased PCE from 18.5% up to 20.3%, which is superior to another additive doping strategy
The effectiveness of An-strategy can be attributed to the construction of a coherent and homogeneous hole transport channel
The hydrophobicity and high glass transition temperature of T-6TPA also granted excellent moisture and thermal stabilities that the initial PCE could remain 80% for 60 days in air or 600 h at 60 °C
This work highlights the synergistical optimization by design of highly hole-mobile materials as well as the interfacial network construction for charge transport.
The interface is crucial for perovskite solar cells
However, voids at interfaces induced by the trapped hygroscopic dimethyl sulfoxide  can reduce charge extraction and accelerate the film degradation, seriously damaging the efficiency and stability
In this work, 4,4'-dinonyl-2,2'-dipyridine , a Lewis base with long alkyl chains is introduced to solve this problem
Theoretical calculated and experimental results confirm that the dipyridyl group on DN-DP can more strongly coordinate with Pb2+ than that of the S=O group on DMSO
The strong coordination effect plays a crucial role in removing the DMSO-based adduct and reducing the formation of voids
Due to the electron-donating properties of pyridine, the existence of DN-DP in the perovskite film can passivate the defects and optimize the energy level alignment of the perovskite configuration
The open-circuit voltage  of the DN-DP-based PSC is improved from 1.107 V  to 1.153 V, giving rise to a power conversion efficiency  of 24.02%
Furthermore, benefiting from the moisture resistance stemming from the hydrophobic nonyl group, the PCE retains 90.4% of the initial performance after 1000 hours of storage in the ambient condition.
Perovskite solar cells  have been shining in the photovoltaic industry, but their fragile stability impedes their commercialization seriously
Here we adopt an ultra-thin film of a functional hydrophobic polymer, polychloro-p-dimethyl benzene , which can largely improve the operational lifetime of PSCs as a surface finish

Chemical vapor deposition  under vacuum is adopted to modify the ultra-thin parylene film, which is thin adequately to afford tunnel contact but is also sufficiently shielding to protect the perovskite layer

Besides, it is demonstrated that the Parylene C film can reduce the perovskite surface defects by interacting with the uncoordinated Pb center and act as an effective hole-hindering barrier in the middle of perovskite and PCBM for decreasing charge recombination
As a result, PSC using a ∼4 nm Parylene C layer exhibits a remarkably increased open-circuit and fill factor and a substantially enhanced efficiency of 21.7 % from pristine 19.4 %
Moreover, the Parylene C-based PSCs have attained long-term thermal and operational stabilities with good reproducibility
Without encapsulation, the degradation was limited to 11 % after 500 h of aging under ambient atmosphere/dark, 85 °C/N2, or constant illumination/ N2 conditions
This work lays a solid foundation for further stability by CVD interface modification.
